case_vignette: an 8-year-old boy presents to the clinic for evaluation of a progressively worsening nail dystrophy that began a few months ago. the patient’s mother denies a family history of skin diseases and reports that her son has no history of medical problems. on physical examination, all of the boy’s fingernails and toenails show hyperkeratosis, longitudinal ridging, loss of luster, and roughness. his hair, skin, and oral mucosa are unremarkable. nail biopsy reveals spongiotic changes and exocytosis of inflammatory cells into the nail epithelia. the results of a fungal culture are negative.
question: What is the final diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Dermatology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask only one question at a time, and it should not be more than 1 line. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. Do not ask the same question multiple times. Ask different questions to cover more information. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain, only give the diagnosis name. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized. You must give only 1 diagnosis otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
My nails have become very rough, they lack shine, and have developed deep lines running along them.
How long have you been experiencing these symptoms?
I've been experiencing these symptoms for a few months now.
Do you have any other symptoms such as joint pain, skin rashes, or changes in your hair?
No, my hair, skin, and oral mucosa are all normal without any issues.
Have you noticed any changes in your nail color or any nail separation from the nail bed?
No, there haven't been any changes in nail color or separation from the nail bed.
Do you have any pre-existing medical conditions or are you currently taking any medications?
I have no history of medical problems and am not taking any medications.
Does anyone in your family have similar nail issues or any other skin related conditions?
No, there is no family history of nail issues or other skin diseases.
Final Diagnosis: Onychorrhexis

The patient notes that their hair, skin, and oral mucosa are normal, and there have been no changes in nail color or separation from the nail bed. The patient has no history of medical problems, is not taking any medications, and there is no family history of nail issues or other skin diseases.
